modelComponent.description: As in earlier versions of the model (Rotstayn et al., 2007), we uniformly increased the emissions of black carbon (by 25%) and organic carbon (by 50%) to improve the agreement between modelled and observed fields of carbonaceous aerosol. Also, the relatively small emissions of BC from aviation were omitted.

componentProperty.value: CMIP5 emission timeseries (monthly from linear interpolation of decadal means).
sulphur dioxide, black carbon (BC), organic carbon (OC)
natural emissions from vegetation of DMS and secondary organic aerosol

gmd:collectiveTitle.gco:CharacterString: Lee, S., H. K. Kim, B. Yan, C. E. Cobb, C. Hennigan, S. Nichols, M. Chamber, E. S. Edgerton, J. J. Jansen, Y. T. Hu, M. Zheng, R. J. Weber and A. G. Russell (2008). Diagnosis of aged prescribed burning plumes impacting an urban area. Environ. Sci. Technol., 42, 1438-1444, doi:10.1021/ES7023059.

Rotstayn, L. D., W. Cai, M. R. Dix, G. D. Farquhar, Y. Feng, P. Ginoux, M. Herzog, A. Ito, J. E. Penner, M. L. Roderick, and M. Wang (2007). Have Australian rainfall and cloudiness increased due to the remote effects of Asian anthropogenic aerosols? J. Geophys. Res., 112, D09202, doi:10.1029/2006JD007712.

modelComponent.description:
There are 11 prognostic variables in the aerosol scheme: dimethyl sulfide (DMS), sulfur dioxide (SO2), sulfate, hydrophobic and hydrophilic forms of black carbon and organic carbon, and four size bins of mineral dust (with radii ranging from 0.1–1, 1–2, 2–3 and 3–6 μm). A further two modes of sea salt are diagnosed as a function of wind speed in the marine boundary layer, but are not treated prognostically. In addition, the distribution of stratospheric aerosol from volcanic eruptions is prescribed using monthly mean data (extended from Sato et al., 1993).
The main reference for the aerosol scheme is Rotstayn et al. (2007). Significant changes since thren are inclusion of dust longwave radiative effects and an updated treatment of dust shortwave effects (Rotstayn et al., 2010). We slightly modified the treatments of indirect aerosol effects from those used by Rotstayn et al. (2010), to avoid the arbitrary tuning of parameters employed in that version of the model. The parameterisation of cloud droplet number concentration is now based on the relation from Jones et al. (1994), with aerosol number concentration derived from the mass concentrations of sulfate, sea salt and hydrophilic carbonaceous aerosol, assuming the same mass-to-number conversion factors that are used in the radiation scheme (Rotstayn et al., 2007).

gmd:collectiveTitle.gco:CharacterString: Rotstayn, L. D., W. Cai, M. R. Dix, G. D. Farquhar, Y. Feng, P. Ginoux, M. Herzog, A. Ito, J. E. Penner, M. L. Roderick, and M. Wang (2007). Have Australian rainfall and cloudiness increased due to the remote effects of Asian anthropogenic aerosols? J. Geophys. Res., 112, D09202, doi:10.1029/2006JD007712.

Rotstayn, L.D., M.A. Collier, M.R. Dix, Y. Feng, H.B. Gordon, S.P. O'Farrell, I.N. Smith and J. Sytkus (2010). "Improved simulation of Australian climate and ENSO-related variability in a global climate model with an interactive aerosol treatment. International Journal of Climatology, 30, 1067-1088.
Sato, M., J. E. Hansen, M. P. McCormick, and J. B. Pollack (1993). Stratospheric aerosol optical depth, 1850– 1990, J. Geophys. Res., 98, 22,987– 22,994.

modelComponent.description:
Transport of aerosols and other trace quantities occurs by advection, vertical turbulent mixing, and vertical transport inside deep convective clouds [Rotstayn and Lohmann, 2002]. Vertical advection is handled using a flux-corrected transport scheme [Van Leer, 1977], and horizontal advection is handled via a semi-Lagrangian scheme [McGregor, 1993]. The treatment of vertical turbulent mixing is based on stability-dependent K-theory [Louis, 1979]. Under convective conditions, an additional nonlocal counter-gradient flux is added [Holtslag and Boville, 1993]. Convective transport is based on the vertical profiles of the updraft mass flux and compensating subsidence generated by the convection scheme [Gregory and Rowntree, 1990].
References and further details in Rotstayn, L. D., and U. Lohmann (2002), Simulation of the tropospheric sulfur cycle in a global model with a physically based cloud scheme, J. Geophys. Res., 107, 4592, doi:10.1029/2002JD002128.

componentProperty.value: Annual-mean CMIP5-recommended total solar irradiance (no factor 0.9965)
Prescribed monthly stratospheric optical depths at 550nm and effective radii, zonally averaged for four altitude bands, extended from Sato et al. (1993).

componentProperty.description: CMIP5-recommended concentrations of long-lived greenhouse gases for the given calendar year (and RCP, where applicable): annual-mean volume concentrations of CO2, CH4, N2O, CFC11,CFC12,CFC22.
CMIP5-recommended monthly mean, spatially varying ozone concentrations from AC&C/SPARC for the given calendar year (and RCP, where applicable).

Annual-mean total solar irradiance (TSI) from CMIP5/SOLARIS for the given calendar year (no factor of 0.9965 applied). 13-yr averaged value (1844 to 1856) used in piControl, sstClim*, abrupt4xCO2, 1pctCO2 and in single-forcing historical runs that use fixed TSI.
Monthly mean prescribed stratospheric sulfate aerosol concentrations for the given calendar year (based on Sato et al., 1993); set to zero from 2000 onwards, and in piControl.

modelComponent.description: Small angle redi isopycnal tensor is used and the Gerdes, Koberle and Willebrand taper is used in the GM scheme. Horizontal diffusion in steep regions is same as GM diffusion.

gmd:organisationName.gco:CharacterString: Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organization in collaboration with Queensland Climate Change Centre of Excellence

modelComponent.description: There is a parameterisation to account for mixing in marginal seas and and in straits. Also to overcome the lack of background horizontal diffusion with the GM scheme, addtional diffusion has been set up near coasts and in closed in emabayments where no mixing was occuring. The amplitude of the mixing is 1.0 e3 multiplied a factor determined by a mask (2 for the Arctic coastline, Western Ross sea, Western Weddell Sea, Timor Straits, Straits of Gibralter . Whilst a value of 4 is used for the Baltic, North Sea, for the less connected parts of the Meditteranian, for the Arabian Gulf and Red sea, for Gulf of Thailand, and Malacca Strait, Gulf of Carpenteria, Hudson bay entrance and Canadian Archipeligo, Gulf of St Lawrence, Irish Sea, Southern gulf of Mexico. When these bays interface to the open ocean the value is stepped down to 2 for the adjacent grid box. There is also extra horizontal mixing around all the coastlines of magnitude 1 e3 m2s-1 the above mask will override this value and additioanl horizontal mixing along the stormtracks determined by the wind stress curl. These additional mixing terms are applied to the upper ocean grid boxes down to 80m depth with the edge mixing down to 280m depth.

gmd:organisationName.gco:CharacterString: Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organization in collaboration with Queensland Climate Change Centre of Excellence

modelComponent.longName: Ocean boundary conditions surface and bed.

gmd:organisationName.gco:CharacterString: Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organization in collaboration with Queensland Climate Change Centre of Excellence
Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organization in collaboration with Queensland Climate Change Centre of Excellence

modelComponent.description: Uses Bryan and lewis background profile to describe interior mixing. This mixing has a latitudinal dependence with reduced valuses in the upper 2000m in the tropical region. from 15N-15S and vlended with the global value between 30n-30S. The global Bryan-Lewis profile is obtained using a tanh expression. Outside the tropics the bacground mixing value is approx 0.3 e-4 m2s-1 in the upper 300m increasing to 1.3e-4 m2s-1 by approx 3000m depth . In the tropics the surface values are reduced above 2000m depth at 1500m =0.2e-4 m2s-1, at 1100m is 0.15e-4 m2s-, at 500m 0.11e-4 m2s-1, at 280m 0.095e-4m2s-1 at 100m is 0.02e-4m2s-1, at 40m 0.002e-4 m2s-1.

gmd:organisationName.gco:CharacterString: Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organization in collaboration with Queensland Climate Change Centre of Excellence

modelComponent.description: Three schemes are included, Kraus Turner which is effective in mid and high latitudes. In the tropics the thermocline mixing is by Interger power scheme Wilson (1999) which is an extension of Pacakanowski and Philander scheme and Price Weller and Pinkel (1986) bulk Richardon number scheme that impacts the tropical mixing and lowers the thermocline depth whilst mainining the thermocline strength that was determined by the integer power scheme.

gmd:organisationName.gco:CharacterString: Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organization in collaboration with Queensland Climate Change Centre of Excellence

documentRelationship.description: The ocean model was upgraded between MK3.0 and Mk3.5, with no further changes for Mk3.6. Details of the upgrades for Mk3.5 are given by Gordon et al. (2010), with a summary in Rotstayn et al. (2010).

modelComponent.description: The sea ice model is part of the atmospheric model code, coupling to the ocean is done at the base of the embedded mixed layer.

componentProperty.value: ice theickness, ice concentration, snow thickness, ice velocities, surface ice/snow temperature

gmd:organisationName.gco:CharacterString: Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organization in collaboration with Queensland Climate Change Centre of Excellence

gmd:collectiveTitle.gco:CharacterString: Gordon, H.B., L.D. Rotstayn, J.L. McGregor, M.R. Dix, E.A. Kowalczyk, S.P. O'Farrell, L.J. Waterman, A.C. Hirst, S.G. Wilson, M.A. Collier, I.G. Watterson and T.I. Elliott (2002). "The CSIRO Mk3 Climate System Model". CSIRO Atmospheric Research Technical Paper No.60, pp1-134.
Gordon, H., S. O'Farrell, M. Collier, M. Dix, L. Rotstayn, E. Kowalczyk, T. Hirst and I. Watterson (2010). "The CSIRO Mk3.5 Climate Model". CAWCR Technical Report No. 021, pp1-74.
O’Farrell, S. P. (1998). "Investigation of the dynamic sea ice component of a coupled atmosphere-sea ice general circulation model", J. Geophys. Res., 103, 15,751– 15,782.

modelComponent.description: The velocities close to the polar are filtered using an fft filter identical to that used in the ocean.

componentProperty.value: formulated in terms of divergence field
25000 * ice depth *ice depth exp (-20 (1- ice conc))

gmd:organisationName.gco:CharacterString: Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organization in collaboration with Queensland Climate Change Centre of Excellence

modelComponent.description: ocean to ice heat flux is rhocw*dz*antarc*(To-Tfi)/((dz/2)**2), where dz is depth of top ocean layer, rhocw (density x heat capicity) =4.1e6, To is ocean temperature in top ocean layer, Tfi is freezing point -1.85 C and antarc =0.075 e-4

componentProperty.value: bare ice 0.65 unless surface temp > -0.2 C then 0.60. Snow albedo 0.80 unless surface temp > -0.05C then 0.70
When new is is formed the volume is mintained but it is gathered into pancake ice 25cm thick
multi-layer on a regular vertical grid

gmd:organisationName.gco:CharacterString: Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organization in collaboration with Queensland Climate Change Centre of Excellence

documentRelationship.description: Changes between Mk3.0 and Mk3.5 are described by Gordon et al. (2010). No changes were made between versions Mk3.5 and Mk3.6

Interactive (single-moment) aerosol scheme, treating sulfate, dust, sea salt and carbonaceous aerosol. Prescribed stratospheric aerosol. Updated shortwave and longwave radiation schemes, including aerosol effects and non-CO2 greenhouse gases. Modified boundary layer treatment, namely, the addition of a non-local counter-gradient flux under convective conditions, augmenting the first order stability-dependent turbulent fluxes already used. See Rotstayn et al. (2010, 2012) for a description of CSIRO-Mk3.6. Previous version (CSIRO-Mk35) is described by Gordon et al. (2010).

simulationRun.description:
Historical simulation with all forcings time varying, except anthropogenic aerosols which were fixed at 1850 levels.
RCP 4.5 forcings were used to extend the experiment from 2006 to 2012.

standard.name: QN_DRS
standard.description: The QN_DRS value allows mapping from data files to metadata being exported from the metadata questionnaire, and contains the institution name, the model name on which the simulation was run, the experiment name to which the simulation conforms, the simulation level base rip value, and finally the given start year for the simulation. The format of the string will thus be: institute_model_experiment_rip_startyear. Also note, that in particular cases, i.e. decadal and noVolc exps, the start date and expdate may differ - this will occur in those cases where the simulation start date is 1st january but still refers to an experiment for the year before. - (see cmip5 experiment design document)

gridTile.description: Horizontal properties: Our ocean grid matches the atmosphere grid, however, there are 2 ocean grid points in the north-south direction for every 1 atmosphere point.
